bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

body.div1:
IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON. NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the matter of the petition of Ah Jack, a Chinaman, for a writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Honorable Cornelius H. Hanford, Judge of said Court:
The United States, having first obtained leave to intervene herein come now and present their petition of intervention, in this cause, and as grounds of intervention say state
FIRST.
That the prayer of the petitioner in this cause ought not to be granted because intervenors say:-
I.
That they deny each and every allegation in the petition filed herein, except, that the said petitioner was apprehended on the 27th day of April, 1894, for being unlawfully in the United States and that on the 30 th day of April, 1894, he was ordered to be deported from the United States to China by C. D. Emery, United States Commissioner.
II.
Intervenors further say that the said petition and prayer thereof should not be granted for the reason that the said Ah Jack is a Chinese laborer, and that he was on the said 27th day of April, 1894, unlawfully in the United States and not entitled to be or remain in the United States.
III.
That the said Ah Jack was on July 14, 1888, arrested and charged with being unlawfullyin the United States; that he was on said day tried upon said charge before C. D. Emery, United States Commission
-2-
-er, he, the said C.D. Emery, having then and there competent jurisdiction to hear, try and determine such charge, and was by the consideration and judgment of said commissioner, ordered and ad- -judged to be unlawfully in the United States, and was then and there by said commissioner ordered deported from the United States and returned to the Province of British Columbia, the foreign country from which he came, and that said C. D. Emery then and there pursuant to said judgment issued his proper writ of deporta- tion, directed to the Marshal of the United States for the District of Washington, commanding the said Marshal to forthwith deport the said Ah Jack from the United States to the Province of British Columbia, and that the said United States Marshal did, without delay, execute the said writ of deportation by taking the said Ah Jack and removing him to the Province of British Columbia.
IV.
And that thereafter, and while said judgment was in full force, unappealed, from and unreversed, the said Ah Jack, on or and about the first day of August, 1888, returned to the United States unlawfully and was again arrested under and by the name of Ah Jap, and charged before said C. D. Emery with being unlawfully in the United States and on the 4th day of August, 1888, the said Ah Jack Jck
